Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Undergraduate Research, October 16-20, 2011 in San Jose, CA.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is to support undergraduate students attending and participating in the Symposium on Undergraduate Research to be held at the Laser Science XXVII Conference, October 16-20, 2011 in San Jose, CA. The symposium will take place on Monday of the conference. Previous years' programs are at http://www.aps.org/units/dls/meetings/symposium/index.cfm. The intellectual merit of this project is to present and disseminate the results of the research work of the participants, mostly from NSF-supported REU programs, and possibly to initiate collaborations among them.

The broader impact is to provide the opportunity for these young students to attend a national meeting of this stature and give their first public talks. A secondary benefit arises because collaborations among them are often born in these sessions since very often students in different universities are involved in similar projects. A third impact is to inaugurate the networking among these students that will be so vital to their future careers as professional scientists, and to encourage them to continue along such a career path.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The eleventh annual Symposium on Undergraduate Research at LS-XXVII took place in San Jose, CA on 17 October, 2011. The Symposium has grown from ten presentations in 2001 to a record forty four this year on projects done at more than 30 universities or research institutes in the US and Europe.    Programs, articles, and photos from past symposia are available at the DLS website http://www.aps.org/units/dls/meetings/symposium/ and the Stony Brook Laser Teaching Center website at  http://laser.physics.sunysb.edu/research-symposium/.

The 2011 Symposium began with a buffet-style welcome dinner on Sunday evening, 16 October, at the Wyndham San Jose Hotel, where most of the students were housed.  Apart from the meal, the features of the evening were informal talks by Thomas Olsen from AIP and Steve Cundiff, outgoing chair of DLS. After the talks, students and mentors lingered for some time in conversations with each other. It was a pleasant time to make acquaintances with one another, enjoy casual time with the mentors there, and discuss the forthcoming adventure. 

The FiO/LS conference events began Monday morning with plenary session talks by several outstanding people. Many of the students attended and were no doubt impressed and inspired by both the excellent talks and the seemingly vast audience of professional scientists.

The Symposium events began at noon with a sandwich lunch for its participants and honored guests, who included Ferenc Krausz, Sir John Pendry, Warren Warren, former DLS chair, Jenny Magnes, and several others.  Students had a chance to chat with them. All of these honored guests offered inspiring words of advice to the young participants.

The poster session stretched from just outside the Glen Ellen room to an attractive, open area that faced a main thoroughfare of the hotel, and thus the venue for our poster session was very well located and attracted many conference participants.  It was chaired by Jenny Magnes of Vassar College.  There was a large volume of traffic by conferees throughout the entire session that occurred during what would normally be the FiO/LS lunch break.  The entire area was abuzz with conversation and discussion as the delighted presenters talked about their work to interested scientists and fellow students.

The oral presentation sessions began at 2:30 and lasted until after 6:00. The first one, with 6 talks, was presided by Justin Peatross of Brigham Young University (he brought eight students to the symposium !), and the second one, also with 6 talks, was presided by Samir Bali of Miami University of Ohio.  Besides students and mentors, the audience included quite a few regular conference attendees over the course of the afternoon. The quality of the talks was uniformly very high, and the two sessions were an unqualified success.

The final Symposium event was a casual buffet dinner at the Sonoma Restaurant, in an open (but covered) court area about 10 minutes walk from the Fairrmont. Students, mentors and conference organizers were joined by several DLS officers, who greatly enjoyed this opportunity to network with students who will be future leaders of the field.

It was gratifying that these very young scientists could give their first presentations at a professional meeting, and it was clearly a memorable event for them.
